Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Complete High-Performance Modeling and Visualization System for Research in Mathematical Biology and Mathematical Geosciences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
North Carolina Agricultural and Technical University (NCA&T), the largest HBCU in North Carolina, will acquire and operate a high performance modeling and visualization system to support active research and training programs in mathematical biology and mathematical geosciences involving faculty from the departments of Energy and Environmental Systems, Physics, Mathematics, Chemistry and Biology with research programs in storm and weather prediction; epidemiology and system biology; protein pathways and blood coagulation; and biological based response models of environmental pollutants. The system will include at least 16 compute nodes, 96 TB of storage and a tiled display wall.

The system will enable broader impacts by supporting work in mathematical biology and mathematical geosciences including the integration of research activities and student development. It will significantly advance research and training activities in mathematical and computational modeling and scientific visualization at NCA&T. The program will synthesize research efforts that link student research engagement with hands-on experience of utilizing the HPC modeling and visualization system to increase the exposure to a larger number of the students and their faculty advisors, including undergraduate students. The cross-cutting nature of the projects that will be supported on the system will be reinforced with integrative classroom learning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Title: MRI: Acquisition of a Complete High-Performance Modeling and Visualization System for Research in Mathematical Biology and Mathematical Geosciences

PI/CO-PIs: Yuh-Lang Lin (PI), Mingxiang Chen, Scott Harrison, Guoqing Tang, and Divi Venkateswarlu

The goal of this project is to establish a consortium composed of research groups in the College of Arts and Sciences at North Carolina Agricultural & Technical State University (NCA&T) to acquire a comprehensive, high-performance computing (HPC) system. This system will be used to enhance the research infrastructure and capability for mathematical modeling and visualizations with applications to (1) the prediction of tropical storms and atmospheric flows over complex terrain, (2) mathematical biology, and (3) computational chemistry. The comprehensive HPC system, which includes (i) one application server and one file server to process large amount of geophysical and biological observation and simulation data, and (ii) a high-capacity disk storage device to store and retrieve data for analysis and visualizations.

The HPC system has been well installed and used by the users to perform computing tasks during the funding period. The HPC cluster system has one head node, 32 computing nodes total in 384 cores in 8 chassis with 64 processors and 96 GB RAM, 1 KVM, 1 NFS storage solution of 96 TB, together with Rock+ management software and Intel compilers. The computing power is almost doubled the originally proposed system. In addition, the large high-resolution display is built in a visual room in Marteena Hall Room 200 on NCAT campus. The HPC cluster is managed by Dr. Nick Luke, a CO-PI of the project. A large number of faculty and students in the Departments of Mathematics, Physics, Energy and Environmental Systems (EES), Biology, and Chemistry have used the cluster extensively.

The Geophysical Science Group, led by Drs. Yuh-Lang Lin and Guoqing Tang, have been using the HPC significantly to preprocess large amount of observed and reanalyzed data for numerical modeling of African easterly waves, hurricane formation, ocean spray effects on hurricanes, landfalling hurricanes and their impacts on orographic rainfall, and mesoscale environments for tornado genesis.  The Computational Biology group has used the HPC cluster and visualization equipment to engage interactive bioinformatics training sessions and cross-departmental collaborations. Specifically, the HPC system located in Room 200 Marteena Hall is now a strategic access point for the northern part of campus to those bioinformatics resources running in Hines Hall and available from supercomputing centers. Dr. Harrison has participated in the training of undergraduate and graduate students from both the biology and mathematics departments over the funding period for this anticipated usage. The computational Chemistry Group, led by Dr. Divi Venkateswarlu, has made significant use of the HPC, processed a large amount of data and published several journal papers. 

During the funding period (10/1/2011-9/30/2015), the PI and CO-PIs have accomplished the above mentioned goals and produce the following results: (1) graduated 4 Ph.D. and 4 M.S. students, (2) published 18 journal papers/book chapters, (3) made 28 conference presentations, (4) created 3 websites (MesoLab, AMCA, and NCAST), and (5) developed and operated a real-time weather forecasting system (NCAST).  Overall, the project has been carried out very successfully and the objectives and tasks have been accomplished.
